webTitle: West Indies beat England by 10 wickets to win series - as it happened

fields.headline: West Indies beat England by 10 wickets to win series - as it happened
fields.standfirst:
• Kemar Roach and Jason Holder get four wickets each in second innings
  • West Indies scoring winning runs in 13 balls

Report: Hapless England lost series in West Indies
fields.trailText: England were defeated with little fuss by West Indies
fields.body:
9.09pm GMT

Here is the report:

Related: West Indies thrash hapless England by 10 wickets to seal series victory

Updated at 9.09pm GMT

8.49pm GMT

England are yet to emerge from the dressing-room. How do you teach application? Answers on the back of an envelope to NW8. The difficulty for England is that the entire batting line-up has the same strengths, the same weaknesses.

Bob Willis agrees: “The batting is a real-real problem. You cannot just go out and play shots. Only Joe Root has any sort of defensive technique. ”

But, hang it! For now let’s be thrilled by the West Indies. By their young bowlers, by Roach, by Holder, by Joseph; their patient batsmen, by Holder again, by Darren Bravo, who single-handedly batted for nearly as long as England’s second-innings.

West Indies win The Wisden Trophy and the whole shebang moves to St Lucia. See you there! Good Night!

Updated at 8.52pm GMT

8.39pm GMT

West Indies beat England by 10 wickets

The party is bubbling at the Sir Viv Richards stadium. The West Indies have a cuddle and exchange stumps, Sir Viv in his blue polo shirt and shades applauds enthusiastically from the stands - and Sir Viv doesn’t clap unless he really means it. Jason Holder smiles and smiles and smiles.

Updated at 8.39pm GMT

8.35pm GMT

3rd over: West Indies 17-0 (Brathwaite 5, Campbell 11) England review an lbw then Campbell pulls Anderson, lofts him, gloriously,over the boundary and that is the West Indies victory!!!

West Indies beat England by 10 wickets to take a 2-0 lead in a three match series.

Updated at 8.37pm GMT

8.32pm GMT

2nd over: West Indies 10-0 (Brathwaite 5, Campbell 5) Campbell clips Broad off his hips for a single, then a tickle for Brathwaite to midwicket for another run. Then Campbell, like a daffodil suddenly bursting into glorious flower, cracks a wide one through the covers, bat finishing up by his shoulder. West Indies need 4 to win.

8.26pm GMT

1st over: West Indies 4-0 (Brathwaite 4, Campbell 0) A boundary from the first ball of Anderson’s over kind of sums up England’s afternoon. A short fat one, cut heartily by Brathwaite. West indies need 10 to win.

8.23pm GMT

So, well, hs;odkjs’odfkjg;askdjf;ksghaskdljfa. West Indies, however, were immense.

Joe Root is stony-faced on the balcony. But what now exactly? I feel rather for Joe Denly, thrown into the lion’s den.

And a killer stat from Jarrod Kimber: “England faced 37 more balls than Darren Bravo did in his innings.”

8.16pm GMT

WICKET! Anderson c Joseph b Holder 0

Anderson misreads Holder’s slower ball and it falls into the hands of Joseph at mid-off. England are all out for 132 and West Indies need 14 to win.

8.14pm GMT

42nd over: England 132-9 (Anderson 0, Curran 13) Curran pings Roach’s slower ball straight back at him he can’t clasp his hands round the grenade -and it riccochets off to the boundary

Did Rome burn to the sound of the Barmy Army singing “We are the Barmies”?

Updated at 8.18pm GMT

8.10pm GMT

41st over: England 126-9 (Anderson 0, Curran 7) Anderson and Curran could almost, almost, be father and son. “Things come and go, Sam. Form. Fortune. But one things never changes - if the batsmen don’t get stuck in, we bowlers are shafted.”

8.05pm GMT

40th over: England 125-9 (Anderson 0, Curran 6) That’s four for 46 now for Kemar Roach whose smile could almost sell a back-stop.

Peter Moores got sacked for drawing in the West Indies. Just saying.

And more discussion on England’s batting:

8.00pm GMT

WICKET! Broad lbw Roach 0

Broad declines to review. He gets turned around by Roach and ball would have cannoned into leg stump. On Sky Atherton ponders that six left-handers make a tasty meal for Roach.

7.59pm GMT

39th over: England 123-8 (Broad 0, Curran 4) Sam Curran. Sam Curran! Sam Curran!! He smashes Holder through the covers to give England the lead. Six big beautiful runs.

7.55pm GMT

WICKET! Buttler lbw Holder 244

Buttler reviewed, but it was more in desperation than certainty. Umpire’s call, the ball just brushing the stumps, but as he had been given out on the field, off he goes.

7.53pm GMT

REVIEW! For an lbw against Buttler...

.

7.53pm GMT

38th over: England 118-7 ( Buttler 24, Curran 0) Foakes just had time to beautifully clip a ball from Roach to the boundary, before one arrived with his name on. Holder is excellent on his review selection, as well as everything else...

7.50pm GMT

WICKET! Foakes lbw Roach 14

Roach sends down one that nips in and raps Foakes on the front pad - not out says the ump, West Indies review straight away and yes - the lights are on and Foakes is on his way.

7.45pm GMT

37th over: England 114-6 ( Buttler 24, Foakes 9) Buttler and Foakes aren’t going to hang around. Boundary or bust is the name of their game. A too-full ball from Holder is sent spinning over mid off by Buttler, then he twists the bat and flicks another four through the leg-side.

7.40pm GMT

36th over: England 106-6 ( Buttler 16, Foakes 9) Ben Foakes, too injured to keep wicket, manages to clop two boundaries from Roach who retaliates with two booming (are there any other sort?) inswingers and hits Foakes on his arm.

7.37pm GMT

35th over: England 98-6 ( Buttler 16, Foakes 1) Holder replaces Gabriel, a run and a leg-bye from it. A few clouds bobble in the bluest of Caribbean skies and the Barmy Army are quieted for now.

7.34pm GMT

34rd over: England 97-6( Buttler 16, Foakes 0) Hark? What it is this? A door closing with a thud, a bolt being pushed into place, the latch falling softly down.

7.31pm GMT

WICKET! Moeen Ali b Roach 4

Oh, Moeen, that wasn’t so pretty. The ball went straight rather than moving away yet Moeen’s feet stood still, while his bat wafted.

7.27pm GMT

33rd over: England 92-5 ( Buttler 16, Moeen 0) Holder keeps Gabriel going and Buttler just leans into a wide one, knee on the dry Antiguan ground, and drives the ball through extra cover for four. England’s happy-go-lucky twosome, Buttler and Moeen, are now their last line of defence.

Robert Wilson is feeling slighted: “How can you complain about an email drought when every time I send you an epic poem about Gordon Greenidge’s limp, you blithely ignore it?

But I’d love an epic poem about Gordon Greenidge’s limp. Anyway:

“Ceci dit, it’s been a long time since I felt this way about a Windies team. I was a huge fan of the quantum phenomenon that was Chanderpaul and various gravity-defying boy-on-the-burning-deck indivdual heroics in the last decade from the likes of Bravo et al but this is a proper unit. How good a skipper must Holder actually be? And how much does it grease the wheels when you first get the gig as an embryo. If this series gets any better, I’m gonna marry it.”

Updated at 7.29pm GMT

7.22pm GMT

32nd over: England 88-5 ( Buttler 12, Moeen 0) The radio tells me that in the last seven years, West Indies have only beaten New Zealand (of the major Test nations) in a series. This could change quite soon. A bad shot by Stokes, who was looking to attack, but chose the wrong shot to the wrong ball.

7.19pm GMT

WICKET! Stokes b Roach 11

Stokes, furious, gloves pulled off in high dudgeon, marches off after dragging a wide one from Roach onto his stumps

7.16pm GMT

31st over: England 88-4 (Stokes 11, Buttler 12) A slightly quieter passage of play in place after tea. Pressure slightly released by Gabriel and Roach - not that they’re bowling badly, just not with quite the intensity of Holder and Joseph. And Buttler leans into a punchy back-foot cover drive and the ball is over the boundary before you can say “large chips please, no vinegar.”

Jimmy Ainsworth has been thinking about Joe Root too: “In response to David Hindle’s gripe, maybe it’s something to do with England consistently picking their best batsman as skipper, which in turn hurts their batting form?”


“A lot of other countries do it as well of course, but if you think of the best captains of the Noughties they were rarely the best batsman - Fleming, Ganguly - or picked as skipper early - Smith and now Holder.


“I remain to be convinced that Root is the right choice for me. He was the class clown before being captain and his post-match platitudes don’t sound like he’s able to read the riot act when things go awry.”

7.10pm GMT

30th over: England 79-4 (Stokes 11, Buttler 8) Kemar Roach takes the ball at the other end, Holder giving himself, and Joseph a rest. Then THWACK a back-foot cover drive from Stokes. That’s more like it.

7.05pm GMT

29th over: England 75-4 (Stokes 7, Buttler 8) To Shannon Gabriel, the first over after tea. Imagine a bus bustling, a big hulking routemaster charging down Oxford Street. Buttler plays and misses to the first ball. Ben Stokes is nearly run-out at the non-strikers end to the third. West Indies start with a maiden.

7.01pm GMT

They’re back on on the field, hold onto your seats, here we go.

6.53pm GMT

England’s sometime batting coach Graham Thorpe is talking on Sky “It’s the application, then it comes down to your thought process, can you be aggressive and will you be aggressive and, along with that ,you’ve got to have the execution” Hmmm. I hope that’s clear to some of you.

6.49pm GMT

TEA

England are dining on a light snack of despair and gumption. West Indies on pure adrenalin. Joseph, 2-12; Holder 2-27 were gorgeously good.

Nasser Hussain has his plain speaking hat on: “This next session is the one we’ve come for, if West Indies win this session, they win the match, they win the series, but they’ve got to get past these two. England have got to make sure that drop from Campbell comes back to haunt them. England have to put a stop to this nonsense.”

Updated at 6.50pm GMT

6.43pm GMT

28th over: England 75-4 (Stokes 7, Buttler 8) One leg bye off Joseph’s over and that’s tea.

What a cracking session. If you’ve got a friend with Sky beg your way over for the supper-session, if only to see West Indies bowlers almost back at their glorious pomp.

6.39pm GMT

27th over: England 74-4 (Stokes 7, Buttler 8) Who’d like Jason Holder on their team? Yes, me too. Inswinger, awayswinger, on a tuppence. Buttler is watchful, manages to send one over the boundary but he’s not comfortable. Itchy shirt, cramped trainers.

Tat Wood writes from New England, “where I’m the only person in a fifty-mile radius who could identify Ian Botham in a police line and, conversely, the one person not to give a toss about Tom Brady. NBC’s showing the Six Nations, forlornly trying to enthuse the septics about a game that isn’t punctuation between adverts. So don’t be downcast: there are people hanging on your every word.”

Thank you Tat! Will you be superbowling?

6.33pm GMT

26th over: England 66-4 (Stokes 2, Buttler 0) Joseph is borderline unplayable this afternoon. He’s a 22 year old beanpole, no overt exuberance, not that you would expect it on such a sad day, but just testing spitting ball after testing spitting ball.

I’m still thinking about Root - i’ll try and look at statsguru at tea and see what his record pre-captaincy was.

This :

6.28pm GMT

25th over: England 61-4 (Stokes 2, Buttler 0) No wickets, no appeals, just another excellent over from Holder.

So how about an email ? Sorry about the address problem earlier: David Hindle has a gripe


“Given that England’s woes stem from calamitous batting, and given how this problem has never really gone away for at least 5 years now it’s interesting that Root’s average just dropped below 50, something I’d
predicted a long time ago.

Why is it no England batsman in the last 60
years could keep their career average over 50 to the end, whilst every other major test nation has had several of their players across multiple
eras do just that, in that same time period?

Surely this is part of what is wrong with England? Whatever “it” may be? The fact with poor Root is
that he is probably nowhere near as good as the early indications of his career suggested. And he got lumped in with 3 other players who are at a
quite different level. Not his fault. But nevertheless. What is going on with English batting? This is a 60 year old problem. And one that is
almost never talked about.

6.25pm GMT

24th over: England 61-4 (Stokes 2, Buttler 0) Drama, what drama! A wicket! Then a huge lbw appeal against Ben Stokes second ball - the Windies slips charge towards the umpire, but decide not to review. Then Stokes is dropped at third slip by John Campbell. And breathe...

6.20pm GMT

WICKET! Denly b Joseph 17

A super delivery from Joseph that moves in as Denly decides he’s got the measure of the ball, lifts his arms in the air and the ball clips the top of off stump.

6.18pm GMT

23rd over: England 59-3 (Denly 17, Buttler 0) Denly scrambles three runs off Holder - scrappy but keeping it ticking, tocking, ticking.

Updated at 6.19pm GMT

6.15pm GMT

22nd over: England 56-3 (Denly 14, Buttler) A huge breakthrough for West Indies, and Joseph didn’t even appeal! England are now in rather a large pile of trouble. And however nervy Denly has been, however inelegant, however wafty -he’s still there while his more illustrious partners have gone on their way

By the way if anyone wants to get in touch I’m on tanya.aldred.freelance@theguardian.com or @tjaldred Twitter.

6.10pm GMT

WICKET! Root c Dowrich b Joseph 7

A breath of a touch on the ball and a cross Root is on his way.

6.08pm GMT

REVIEW....

for caught behind against Joe Root...

6.07pm GMT

21st over: England 54-2 (Denly 14, Root 5) Root flicks dangerously at Holder but the acrobatically diving Shane Dowrich can’t get a hand on it and it wobbles over the boundary for four. Then a monstrous, double-handed, lbw appeal against Denly to a ball that nips in. But Holder didn’t have the courage of his convictions - which was lucky as it was very much not out. England trail by 65.

Updated at 6.07pm GMT

6.01pm GMT

20th over: England 49-2 (Denly 14, Root 0) Denly tries another pull shot, off Alzarri Joseph - DONT DO IT JOE! -it is an unsuccessful and awkward looking as the other four. Joseph bowling beautifully, and unbelievably composed after the death of his mother this morning. Another maiden.

5.57pm GMT

19th over: England 49-2 (Denly 14, Root 0) Holder’s liquid run-up is bootiful to watch. Root pulls away just as Holder is about to release his third ball - very late, but luckily for him Holder is not one to hold a grudge. A maiden.

5.53pm GMT

18th over: England 49-2 (Denly 14, Root 0) England trail by 70. And Denly looks on borrowed time.

Updated at 6.16pm GMT

5.52pm GMT

17th over: England 49-2 (Denly 14, Root 0) Thanks Nick and hello everyone who hasn’t got anything better to do on a Saturday night than idly browse the OBO. Anyway, that was a killer over from Jason Holder straight after drinks. The first ball went for four leg-byes; Bairstow nearly dragged the second onto his stumps. And the fourth. He finally got himself out to the sixth,with a flamboyant fling at a ball that ducked in.

5.48pm GMT

WICKET! Bairstow b Holder 14

Arghgh - having nearly survived a torrid over, Bairstow’s head is no-where and his stumps are splayed.If you can remember that old advert featuring Ian Botham “he’d rather be out driving his Saab” - that.

Updated at 5.49pm GMT

5.41pm GMT

That’s drinks, so with that it’s time for Tanya Aldred, who will be your guide for the rest of the day. Emails to her - Tanya.Aldred.casual@theGuardian.com.

5.40pm GMT

16th over: England 43-1 (Denly 14, Bairstow 8) Bowling change, as Joseph replaces Gabriel. Denly manages to avoid repeating the first innings when he snicked the loosest of looseners through to the keeper, but is beaten by a lovely Joseph away-nipper before wearing a lifter on his hand. Still not easy out there.

5.36pm GMT

15th over: England 43-1 (Denly 14, Bairstow 8) Bairstow jabs a pull off his thigh round the corner and sprints back for a second run, then after missing a cut he plays quite a careful pull from a stinking long-hop just in front of deep backward square, out to the boundary. Just as in the first knock, positivity from Bairstow here.

5.32pm GMT

14th over: England 37-1 (Denly 14, Bairstow 2) Gabriel still steaming in, and he’s opting for a rib-tickling approach, pounding the middle of the track. One stays super low and Denly keeps it from hitting the stumps only with a thick inside edge, then he wafts at a rare full ball and misses with the drive.

5.27pm GMT

13th over: England 37-1 (Denly 14, Bairstow 2) Hell’s teeth that was a dreadful shot by Burns. Bairstow is altogether more circumspect with the remaining five balls of the over, getting off the mark by flicking two into a vacant mid-wicket.

5.22pm GMT

WICKET! Burns c Campbell b Holder 16 - England 35-1

Sheesh. Holder brings himself on and strikes first ball, but at the risk of being uncharitable it didn’t have much to do with him. Burns tries to cut a ball far, far too close to cut, and only succeeds in giving Campbell catching practice in the slips.

5.21pm GMT

12th over: England 35-0 (Burns 16, Denly 14) Gabriel is giving off similar grumpy vibes to Anderson earlier. The nip has disappeared from his bowling and the two batsmen are finding it increasingly easy to play him. Just a single from the over.

5.15pm GMT

11th over: England 34-0 (Burns 15, Denly 14) Denly clips pleasantly in front of mid-wicket, not quite timing it perfectly but he picks up another two runs, and as it turns out it was merely a precursor to an absolutely delicious cover drive that he very much did time perfectly, all the way to the cover fence. If you’re an England supporter who believes in fate-tempting look away now...but these two are looking more and more assured.

5.10pm GMT

10th over: England 28-0 (Burns 15, Denly 8) Snorter from Gabriel who turns Burns right round, like a record baby, and he somehow avoids getting bat on the ball. Incidentally, Bairstow is padded up to come in first drop, despite keeping for four sessions.

5.05pm GMT

9th over: England 28-0 (Burns 15, Denly 8) Burns jabs at one from Roach then looks behind him in panicked deja vu, the ball going extremely close to the stumps, much as it did in the first innings. But unlike that innings, it missed the wickets and he survives.

5.01pm GMT

8th over: England 26-0 (Burns 14, Denly 7) Gabriel traps Denly and it looks very, very close: the bowler wants to review it but none of his teammates concur. Looked out at first glance, but Hawkeye confirms it was going a few inches over, so a good decision in the end. Denly looks uncomfortable in the extreme, but then Gabriel lets him off the hook with a wide long-hop that the Kent man cuts with gusto to the boundary. Then once more Denly gets away with one, cuffing an attempted pull straight up in the air, but it plops down just in front of a theoretical square leg.

4.56pm GMT

7th over: England 21-0 (Burns 14, Denly 2) Burns looking a bit more positive: he whips a couple down to fine leg, plays a confident drive straight at extra-cover then times the knickers off a leg-stump half-volley, which fine leg fails to stop. There was a missed cut in there too, but the intent is there.

Updated at 4.56pm GMT

4.54pm GMT

6th over: England 14-0 (Burns 8, Denly 1) Denly looks a tad skittish, all tip-toes and jerky bat movements. He pulls at one from Gabriel that keeps a little lower than expected and he misses in ugly fashion, but then he connects with one, sends a top edge high, high, high in the air towards fine leg where Brathwaite runs in....and DROPS! Those steeplers are always tricky but he made a complete nonsense of the attempt, misjudging things badly and not getting there quite in time. Gabriel screams then stares at the fielder for a long, long time. Gulp.

Meanwhile: mercy, mercy me...

4.46pm GMT

5th over: England 13-0 (Burns 8, Denly 0) Burns plays with soft hands, opening the face very slightly and guiding a thick outside edge down to third man for England’s first boundary off the bat. Roach comes back with the jaffa’s jaffa from the last ball of the over, which misses the edge but does square Burns up rather.

4.44pm GMT

The players are back out for the afternoon. You wonder how long West Indies will be able to keep up their barrage of that brief spell before lunch. If they can, this will be a super-spicy session for England.

4.29pm GMT

They’re playing highlights of Lara’s 375 in Antigua on Sky. Here’s a piece about that magnificent thing by Vic Marks, who watched from the press box that day.

Related: The Spin | Three minutes from history: my commentary box view of Lara’s 375

4.05pm GMT

Lunch: England 9-0, West Indies lead by 110 runs

Pretty decent morning for England, really: the lead was only extended by 34 runs, and they’ve reached the break with all their wickets intact. A low bar, perhaps, but that’s frankly where England have set it on this tour so far.

4.04pm GMT

4th over: England 9-0 (Burns 4, Denly 0) Burns takes a Trottian length of time to mark out his guard, just making sure this is the last over before lunch. He plays out the over well, not offering the bat unless he absolutely has to, flapping a single to fine leg and it is indeed the interval. A potentially grim little spell nicely dealt with by the openers.

3.58pm GMT

3rd over: England 8-0 (Burns 3, Denly 0) Roach bowls with a hefty grunt, but Burns deals with him pretty well, nicely flicking a single down to fine leg. Denly shovels one to short-leg which Hetmyer drops, but that was all thigh pad. They go up for an ear-splitting lbw appeal but the angle from which Roach is bowling (wide) that looked like it was heading comfortably down leg. Shrewd call not to review it.

3.54pm GMT

2nd over: England 7-0 (Burns 2, Denly 0) Here’s beefcake Shannon Gabriel to open from the other end, and sends a brutal bouncer towards Burns’s throat which he fends off as best he can, the ball flying to where leg gully would have been. Batting on this track against this pace looks...not fun.

Meanwhile, the Antipodean mind games continue, with Justin Rigden: “Please remind Brian Withington that our bragging rights disappeared with that little scrap of sandpaper last year. I told you England would be batting in half an hour. If they survive until the last session today, it’s game on.”

3.48pm GMT

1st over: England 6-0 (Burns 1, Denly 0) Quite a start from Roach - an absolutely colossal leg side wide gives a scrambling Dowrich no chance at all, and it flies away for five wides. Then the snortiest of snorter bouncers is aimed at Burns’s nose: a brilliant delivery, jagging in as well as being at that lethal length and pace, very well played by Burns who got out of the way, pronto. Burns tucks the first run off the bat just wide of mid-on.

3.45pm GMT

They’re out for England’s second innings. How will this water biscuit England top order cope with Roach, Gabriel et al?

3.38pm GMT

Great effort by Bravo, though. He reached 50 off 215 balls and in 338 minutes, which makes it the slowest ever half-century by a West Indian and the third slowest in all Test matches. Proper cricket, or something.

3.37pm GMT

West Indies lead by 119 runs

Tough one for England, then. The bad news is this pitch is becoming more treacherous than the pit of Sarlaac, but the good news is West Indies have shown it’s possible to score some runs if you’re sensible about it.

3.36pm GMT

WICKET! Bravo st Bairstow b Ali 50 - West Indies 306 all out

After Bravo brings up his half-century with a single, two balls of the over to go they for some reason take another single after a thump down to long-on by Gabriel. Bravo comes down the pitch to try working another to keep the strike, but just runs past it and Bairstow completes the formalities.

Updated at 4.05pm GMT

3.29pm GMT

130th over: West Indies 304-9 (Bravo 49, Gabriel 0) Gabriel loses track of what I think was a shorter slower ball, but is again pretty staunchly in behind the rest of Stokes’s over.

“Please advise Justin Ridgen (over 124),” advises Brian Withington, “that we are on to his canny reverse moxing of this match and the forthcoming Ashes series. Stick to the archetypal Antipodean bragging and sledging whilst leaving us Poms to the gentle deprecatory pursuit of downplaying our teams’ chances on all sporting fronts.”

3.27pm GMT

129th over: West Indies 304-9 (Bravo 49, Gabriel 0) Bit of spin, as Mo Mo Mo Ali replaces Anderson. “Let’s not eff about Mo,” yells a voice from somewhere, I think the crowd rather than the field, but one would think the players will concur. Bravo turns down a single after carving one to the cover sweeper, which is a bit surprising, but then takes a step or two down and smokes a bullet straight six that barely got 10ft above the ground. However he can’t get the single from the final ball which means Stokes, in theory, has an over at Gabriel.

3.22pm GMT

128th over: West Indies 298-9 (Bravo 43, Gabriel 0) England put three slips, a short leg and a leg gully in for Gabriel, but the big man gets in behind the rest of the over from Stokes pretty solidly, ducking under a couple of the shorter balls. Wicket maiden from Stokes though.

3.19pm GMT

WICKET! Joseph c Burns b Stokes 7 - West Indies 298-9

Ben Stokes is on, and strikes with his very first ball, as Joseph fends one to Rory Burns, who takes a good low catch at third slip. That’s what you call instant impact.

3.17pm GMT

127th over: West Indies 298-8 (Bravo 43, Joseph 7) Joseph takes a rapid single just past point, but speeds in and makes his ground, but the throw misses anyway.

3.14pm GMT

Meanwhile here’s a story from Ali Martin about the Hundred, which is going well.

Related: PCA warns The Hundred could create ‘super-counties’ in domestic cricket

3.12pm GMT

126th over: West Indies 296-8 (Bravo 42, Joseph 6) Joseph fends at a couple of balls from Broad that leap up, inspiring the installation of a short leg. Joseph gets in solidly behind a few, before another pops up but too far ahead of Jennings to be dangerous.

Digging in, with Darren Bravo:

3.07pm GMT

125th over: West Indies 296-8 (Bravo 42, Joseph 6) Sheesh what a shot from Joseph: a ball of reasonably full length is thwacked high over Anderson head and it bounces through for a boundary. Bravo then plays a couple of shots that look a bit pointless and wafty, missing both, but then again he’s facing Jimmy Anderson on a minefield of a pitch, so...

3.04pm GMT

They’re having a drink. West Indies lead by 104 which, after the first hour, is a result for both teams: them because, well, they lead by 104, but England because they’ve broadly kept the scoring down.

3.01pm GMT

124th over: West Indies 291-8 (Bravo 42, Joseph 1) Joseph plays a nice flick off his pads for a single. The optimistic Justin Rigden from earlier is back on - or, perhaps given his provenance, the pessimistic Justin Rigden. “I am an Australian and did watch England in the 1990s, with a great deal of satisfaction! This is a much better England team than that. They’ll be batting within half an hour - providing the top end are patient, they should make a game of it. They’ll beat Australia this year too.”

2.57pm GMT

123rd over: West Indies 289-8 (Bravo 41, Joseph 0) Applause from all round the stadium as Alzarri Joseph makes his way out to the middle. He leaves one that misses off stump by...not a lot, and then takes one on his pads that England sort of appeal for, but their heart didn’t sound in it.

2.53pm GMT

WICKET! Roach c Stokes b Anderson 6 - West Indies 289-8

Really, really good catch by Stokes: not a spectacular one really, because he didn’t have to move his feet and just threw his hands up high directly above his head, but a flashed edge from Roach was going at quite a pace. England chipping away now: Anderson and Broad have bowled rather well.

2.52pm GMT

122nd over: West Indies 289-7 (Bravo 41, Roach 6) Bravo wears a nasty lifter from Broad on his bottom hand, and that looked like it bloody hurt. Glove off, hand gets a good shake, then next ball from almost the same length keeps very low and Bravo does brilliantly to jab his bat down in time. Then Broad bowls a couple of what look a lot like cutters, the first beats a defensive push and the next goes wide of a rare expansive shot from Bravo. The Windies have the last laugh (from that over) with a couple of singles.

Meanwhile, this is flamboyantly niche...

...and while I’m not trying to explain the joke, any excuse to listen to one of the great songs.

2.46pm GMT

121st over: West Indies 287-7 (Bravo 40, Roach 5) Roach jabs at one outside off and a very thick edge zoots wide of the diving Burns at fourth slip, earning himself (?) a boundary.

2.42pm GMT

120th over: West Indies 282-7 (Bravo 39, Roach 1) You have to admire Kemar Roach’s moxy: he swings absolutely everything at a ball vaguely on a length, misses it by a foot and earns a quizzical look from Broad.

2.41pm GMT

119th over: West Indies 282-7 (Bravo 39, Roach 1) Actually I did Anderson a disservice there: there was plenty of bounce, enough in fact to take Holder’s glove, rather than the bat. Anderson beats Bravo with a couple of absolutely snorting away swingers and, despite his continued grumpiness, looks in a pretty good groove.

“Every time I see England selector Ed Smith in the crowd,” offers Don Wilson, “I’ve been trying to think who he reminds me of. Today I’ve got it, anyone remember 1980’s early CGi Max Headroom?”

Judge for yourself...

...although I’ve always had him more as ‘Young Mick McCarthy if he went to Cambridge.’

2.34pm GMT

WICKET! Holder c Bairstow b Anderson 22 - West Indies 281-7

Simple stuff. Anderson bowls one just the right width outside off stump, it lifts up just enough and flicks off Holders’s willow through to Bairstow.

2.33pm GMT

118th over: West Indies 281-6 (Bravo 39, Holder 22) There’s a significant change in the field, as Root and Broad bring in a short leg and a sort of leg gully/wide leg slip, with one conventional slip and a gully. Not going to be much full stuff, you’d wager. Incidentally, should probably have mentioned earlier: that short-leg is Keaton Jennings, on the field again for Ben Foakes, so Jonny Bairstow is keeping. Jennings takes a sharp one-handed catch, but off Bravo’s thigh pad.

Kandukuru Nagarjun writes: “Alzarri Joseph’s tragedy reminds me of another tragedy involving a Windies player that happened around an Antigua Test. In 1983 against India, the great Gordon Greenidge scored a century, his first for six years. And then flew back home to Barbados to be with his infant daughter battling a kidney infection. Sadly, she succumbed to it two days later.”

2.27pm GMT

117th over: West Indies 281-6 (Bravo 39, Holder 22) Anderson lets out a gutteral scream of irritation as Holder edges between second and third slip, but it dropped about a foot short and in the end Stokes does brilliantly to stop the thing from scooting boundary-wards. Anderson beats the edge two more times, and turns on his heels with what can only be described as a dejected vibe.

2.23pm GMT

116th over: West Indies 280-6 (Bravo 38, Holder 22) Broad hits Bravo above the knee roll and goes up for an appeal that could go in the dictionary as the definition of optimism. That’s what happens when desperation starts to creep in. One single from the over, nudged by Bravo.

2.19pm GMT

115th over: West Indies 279-6 (Bravo 37, Holder 22) Holder leaves one on length, which is about as remarkable an act of faith as you can imagine in cricket. He was right though: just, the ball going about three or four inches over the bails.

Updated at 2.22pm GMT

2.15pm GMT

114th over: West Indies 278-6 (Bravo 36, Holder 22) Broad gives Bravo a terrific lifter which the batsman does well to keep down but then, in a minor version of the stunt he pulled yesterday, the bowler pointlessly flicks the ball at the stumps, off which it rebounds, and the alert Windies pair skip through for a single. Then a sign of just how much this pitch is falling apart as one on a length leaps up so much that it loops through to the keeper - it was as if the ball had hit a pebble in the middle of the pitch.

2.10pm GMT

113th over: West Indies 277-6 (Bravo 35, Holder 22) Absolute woofer of an in-ducker from Anderson to start, cutting Holder in half and from the sound of things it clipped his box. Then one holds its line and beats the outside edge, and the final ball of the over is the sort of sensational ball that even the best batsmen just has to close his eyes and hope misses the bat, pitching on middle-off and jagging away unplayably.

Justin Rigden potentially didn’t grow up watching England in the 1990s, so thus sounds quite chipper. “Of course England will be batting today, the Windies tail is quite fragile. This pitch will be horrendous to bat on last. If England can get a lead of 100 they’re in with a good chance of victory.”

2.05pm GMT

112th over: West Indies 277-6 (Bravo 35, Holder 22) Broad starts largely on the mark, but Holder gets some squirted runs, two down to third man and another one off a thick inside-edge to mid-wicket. Bravo tucks a couple of his own down to fine leg.

2.03pm GMT

And we’re away. The Barmy Army, as usual give themselves a hearty round of applause after the semi-tuneless version of Jerusalem.

2.02pm GMT

More sad news, from Antigua...

As far as I know Joseph - just 22 - will still play, which always I find absolutely extraordinary. The mental fortitude that must take is remarkable.

1.59pm GMT

This has nothing to do with sport, never mind cricket, but before play starts read these tributes to Jeremy Hardy, who died this week.

Related: '100% filled with mirth!' Comedians pay tribute to Jeremy Hardy

1.55pm GMT

“Of course England will be batting at some point today,” says Nick Knight.

Don’t be quite so sure about that, Nicholas.

1.42pm GMT

What’s the pitch going to be like today? Well, it looks like an eroding cliff, all jagged edges and unexpected crevices. I wouldn’t fancy batting on it, but then again I’m not even a village standard batsman. Batting last on this is going to be spicy, but batting second and third doesn’t look like a picnic either.

1.37pm GMT

And here’s Stuart Broad sounding either despondent or rather bullish, depending on how you view things.

Related: England’s Stuart Broad feels ‘lost’ after day of frustration in the field

1.35pm GMT

A quick catch-up from yesterday? Allow Victor Marks to take you through it.

Related: Stuart Broad earns just reward but England sleepwalk towards oblivion

12.44pm GMT

Preamble

Do you think there’s a more frustrated set of sportspeople in the world right now than the England bowling attack? 276/6 isn’t a horrendous score to have conceded in isolation, even without the dropped catches. But of course there are the dropped catches, plus the house of cards collapse of the top order, which has meant that not horrendous score equates to what will soon be a first innings lead of 100, then 150 and most likely 200 plus after that.

Naturally England didn’t bowl perfectly, and we’ll get to the West Indies batting prowess in a bit, but if the tourists’ current predicament is anyone specific’s fault, it ain’t the bowlers’.

Naturally, the Guardian reserves the right to withdraw this commentary should we get another wicketless day with a whole load of pies sent down. Let’s see.
fields.bodyText: Here is the report: England are yet to emerge from the dressing-room. How do you teach application? Answers on the back of an envelope to NW8. The difficulty for England is that the entire batting line-up has the same strengths, the same weaknesses. Bob Willis agrees: “The batting is a real-real problem. You cannot just go out and play shots. Only Joe Root has any sort of defensive technique. ” But, hang it! For now let’s be thrilled by the West Indies. By their young bowlers, by Roach, by Holder, by Joseph; their patient batsmen, by Holder again, by Darren Bravo, who single-handedly batted for nearly as long as England’s second-innings. West Indies win The Wisden Trophy and the whole shebang moves to St Lucia. See you there! Good Night! The party is bubbling at the Sir Viv Richards stadium. The West Indies have a cuddle and exchange stumps, Sir Viv in his blue polo shirt and shades applauds enthusiastically from the stands - and Sir Viv doesn’t clap unless he really means it. Jason Holder smiles and smiles and smiles. 3rd over: West Indies 17-0 (Brathwaite 5, Campbell 11) England review an lbw then Campbell pulls Anderson, lofts him, gloriously,over the boundary and that is the West Indies victory!!! West Indies beat England by 10 wickets to take a 2-0 lead in a three match series. 2nd over: West Indies 10-0 (Brathwaite 5, Campbell 5) Campbell clips Broad off his hips for a single, then a tickle for Brathwaite to midwicket for another run. Then Campbell, like a daffodil suddenly bursting into glorious flower, cracks a wide one through the covers, bat finishing up by his shoulder. West Indies need 4 to win. 1st over: West Indies 4-0 (Brathwaite 4, Campbell 0) A boundary from the first ball of Anderson’s over kind of sums up England’s afternoon. A short fat one, cut heartily by Brathwaite. West indies need 10 to win. So, well, hs;odkjs’odfkjg;askdjf;ksghaskdljfa. West Indies, however, were immense. Joe Root is stony-faced on the balcony. But what now exactly? I feel rather for Joe Denly, thrown into the lion’s den. And a killer stat from Jarrod Kimber: “England faced 37 more balls than Darren Bravo did in his innings.” Anderson misreads Holder’s slower ball and it falls into the hands of Joseph at mid-off. England are all out for 132 and West Indies need 14 to win. 42nd over: England 132-9 (Anderson 0, Curran 13) Curran pings Roach’s slower ball straight back at him he can’t clasp his hands round the grenade -and it riccochets off to the boundary Did Rome burn to the sound of the Barmy Army singing “We are the Barmies”? 41st over: England 126-9 (Anderson 0, Curran 7) Anderson and Curran could almost, almost, be father and son. “Things come and go, Sam. Form. Fortune. But one things never changes - if the batsmen don’t get stuck in, we bowlers are shafted.” 40th over: England 125-9 (Anderson 0, Curran 6) That’s four for 46 now for Kemar Roach whose smile could almost sell a back-stop. Peter Moores got sacked for drawing in the West Indies. Just saying. And more discussion on England’s batting: Broad declines to review. He gets turned around by Roach and ball would have cannoned into leg stump. On Sky Atherton ponders that six left-handers make a tasty meal for Roach. 39th over: England 123-8 (Broad 0, Curran 4) Sam Curran. Sam Curran! Sam Curran!! He smashes Holder through the covers to give England the lead. Six big beautiful runs. Buttler reviewed, but it was more in desperation than certainty. Umpire’s call, the ball just brushing the stumps, but as he had been given out on the field, off he goes. . 38th over: England 118-7 ( Buttler 24, Curran 0) Foakes just had time to beautifully clip a ball from Roach to the boundary, before one arrived with his name on. Holder is excellent on his review selection, as well as everything else... Roach sends down one that nips in and raps Foakes on the front pad - not out says the ump, West Indies review straight away and yes - the lights are on and Foakes is on his way. 37th over: England 114-6 ( Buttler 24, Foakes 9) Buttler and Foakes aren’t going to hang around. Boundary or bust is the name of their game. A too-full ball from Holder is sent spinning over mid off by Buttler, then he twists the bat and flicks another four through the leg-side. 36th over: England 106-6 ( Buttler 16, Foakes 9) Ben Foakes, too injured to keep wicket, manages to clop two boundaries from Roach who retaliates with two booming (are there any other sort?) inswingers and hits Foakes on his arm. 35th over: England 98-6 ( Buttler 16, Foakes 1) Holder replaces Gabriel, a run and a leg-bye from it. A few clouds bobble in the bluest of Caribbean skies and the Barmy Army are quieted for now. 34rd over: England 97-6( Buttler 16, Foakes 0) Hark? What it is this? A door closing with a thud, a bolt being pushed into place, the latch falling softly down. Oh, Moeen, that wasn’t so pretty. The ball went straight rather than moving away yet Moeen’s feet stood still, while his bat wafted. 33rd over: England 92-5 ( Buttler 16, Moeen 0) Holder keeps Gabriel going and Buttler just leans into a wide one, knee on the dry Antiguan ground, and drives the ball through extra cover for four. England’s happy-go-lucky twosome, Buttler and Moeen, are now their last line of defence. Robert Wilson is feeling slighted: “How can you complain about an email drought when every time I send you an epic poem about Gordon Greenidge’s limp, you blithely ignore it? But I’d love an epic poem about Gordon Greenidge’s limp. Anyway: “Ceci dit, it’s been a long time since I felt this way about a Windies team. I was a huge fan of the quantum phenomenon that was Chanderpaul and various gravity-defying boy-on-the-burning-deck indivdual heroics in the last decade from the likes of Bravo et al but this is a proper unit. How good a skipper must Holder actually be? And how much does it grease the wheels when you first get the gig as an embryo. If this series gets any better, I’m gonna marry it.” 32nd over: England 88-5 ( Buttler 12, Moeen 0) The radio tells me that in the last seven years, West Indies have only beaten New Zealand (of the major Test nations) in a series. This could change quite soon. A bad shot by Stokes, who was looking to attack, but chose the wrong shot to the wrong ball. Stokes, furious, gloves pulled off in high dudgeon, marches off after dragging a wide one from Roach onto his stumps 31st over: England 88-4 (Stokes 11, Buttler 12) A slightly quieter passage of play in place after tea. Pressure slightly released by Gabriel and Roach - not that they’re bowling badly, just not with quite the intensity of Holder and Joseph. And Buttler leans into a punchy back-foot cover drive and the ball is over the boundary before you can say “large chips please, no vinegar.” Jimmy Ainsworth has been thinking about Joe Root too: “In response to David Hindle’s gripe, maybe it’s something to do with England consistently picking their best batsman as skipper, which in turn hurts their batting form?” “A lot of other countries do it as well of course, but if you think of the best captains of the Noughties they were rarely the best batsman - Fleming, Ganguly - or picked as skipper early - Smith and now Holder. “I remain to be convinced that Root is the right choice for me. He was the class clown before being captain and his post-match platitudes don’t sound like he’s able to read the riot act when things go awry.” 30th over: England 79-4 (Stokes 11, Buttler 8) Kemar Roach takes the ball at the other end, Holder giving himself, and Joseph a rest. Then THWACK a back-foot cover drive from Stokes. That’s more like it. 29th over: England 75-4 (Stokes 7, Buttler 8) To Shannon Gabriel, the first over after tea. Imagine a bus bustling, a big hulking routemaster charging down Oxford Street. Buttler plays and misses to the first ball. Ben Stokes is nearly run-out at the non-strikers end to the third. West Indies start with a maiden. They’re back on on the field, hold onto your seats, here we go. England’s sometime batting coach Graham Thorpe is talking on Sky “It’s the application, then it comes down to your thought process, can you be aggressive and will you be aggressive and, along with that ,you’ve got to have the execution” Hmmm. I hope that’s clear to some of you. England are dining on a light snack of despair and gumption. West Indies on pure adrenalin. Joseph, 2-12; Holder 2-27 were gorgeously good. Nasser Hussain has his plain speaking hat on: “This next session is the one we’ve come for, if West Indies win this session, they win the match, they win the series, but they’ve got to get past these two. England have got to make sure that drop from Campbell comes back to haunt them. England have to put a stop to this nonsense.” 28th over: England 75-4 (Stokes 7, Buttler 8) One leg bye off Joseph’s over and that’s tea. What a cracking session. If you’ve got a friend with Sky beg your way over for the supper-session, if only to see West Indies bowlers almost back at their glorious pomp. 27th over: England 74-4 (Stokes 7, Buttler 8) Who’d like Jason Holder on their team? Yes, me too. Inswinger, awayswinger, on a tuppence. Buttler is watchful, manages to send one over the boundary but he’s not comfortable. Itchy shirt, cramped trainers. Tat Wood writes from New England, “where I’m the only person in a fifty-mile radius who could identify Ian Botham in a police line and, conversely, the one person not to give a toss about Tom Brady. NBC’s showing the Six Nations, forlornly trying to enthuse the septics about a game that isn’t punctuation between adverts. So don’t be downcast: there are people hanging on your every word.” Thank you Tat! Will you be superbowling? 26th over: England 66-4 (Stokes 2, Buttler 0) Joseph is borderline unplayable this afternoon. He’s a 22 year old beanpole, no overt exuberance, not that you would expect it on such a sad day, but just testing spitting ball after testing spitting ball. I’m still thinking about Root - i’ll try and look at statsguru at tea and see what his record pre-captaincy was. This : 25th over: England 61-4 (Stokes 2, Buttler 0) No wickets, no appeals, just another excellent over from Holder. So how about an email ? Sorry about the address problem earlier: David Hindle has a gripe “Given that England’s woes stem from calamitous batting, and given how this problem has never really gone away for at least 5 years now it’s interesting that Root’s average just dropped below 50, something I’d predicted a long time ago. Why is it no England batsman in the last 60 years could keep their career average over 50 to the end, whilst every other major test nation has had several of their players across multiple eras do just that, in that same time period? Surely this is part of what is wrong with England? Whatever “it” may be? The fact with poor Root is that he is probably nowhere near as good as the early indications of his career suggested. And he got lumped in with 3 other players who are at a quite different level. Not his fault. But nevertheless. What is going on with English batting? This is a 60 year old problem. And one that is almost never talked about. 24th over: England 61-4 (Stokes 2, Buttler 0) Drama, what drama! A wicket! Then a huge lbw appeal against Ben Stokes second ball - the Windies slips charge towards the umpire, but decide not to review. Then Stokes is dropped at third slip by John Campbell. And breathe... A super delivery from Joseph that moves in as Denly decides he’s got the measure of the ball, lifts his arms in the air and the ball clips the top of off stump. 23rd over: England 59-3 (Denly 17, Buttler 0) Denly scrambles three runs off Holder - scrappy but keeping it ticking, tocking, ticking. 22nd over: England 56-3 (Denly 14, Buttler) A huge breakthrough for West Indies, and Joseph didn’t even appeal! England are now in rather a large pile of trouble. And however nervy Denly has been, however inelegant, however wafty -he’s still there while his more illustrious partners have gone on their way By the way if anyone wants to get in touch I’m on tanya.aldred.freelance@theguardian.com or @tjaldred Twitter. A breath of a touch on the ball and a cross Root is on his way. for caught behind against Joe Root... 21st over: England 54-2 (Denly 14, Root 5) Root flicks dangerously at Holder but the acrobatically diving Shane Dowrich can’t get a hand on it and it wobbles over the boundary for four. Then a monstrous, double-handed, lbw appeal against Denly to a ball that nips in. But Holder didn’t have the courage of his convictions - which was lucky as it was very much not out. England trail by 65. 20th over: England 49-2 (Denly 14, Root 0) Denly tries another pull shot, off Alzarri Joseph - DONT DO IT JOE! -it is an unsuccessful and awkward looking as the other four. Joseph bowling beautifully, and unbelievably composed after the death of his mother this morning. Another maiden. 19th over: England 49-2 (Denly 14, Root 0) Holder’s liquid run-up is bootiful to watch. Root pulls away just as Holder is about to release his third ball - very late, but luckily for him Holder is not one to hold a grudge. A maiden. 18th over: England 49-2 (Denly 14, Root 0) England trail by 70. And Denly looks on borrowed time. 17th over: England 49-2 (Denly 14, Root 0) Thanks Nick and hello everyone who hasn’t got anything better to do on a Saturday night than idly browse the OBO. Anyway, that was a killer over from Jason Holder straight after drinks. The first ball went for four leg-byes; Bairstow nearly dragged the second onto his stumps. And the fourth. He finally got himself out to the sixth,with a flamboyant fling at a ball that ducked in. Arghgh - having nearly survived a torrid over, Bairstow’s head is no-where and his stumps are splayed.If you can remember that old advert featuring Ian Botham “he’d rather be out driving his Saab” - that. That’s drinks, so with that it’s time for Tanya Aldred, who will be your guide for the rest of the day. Emails to her - Tanya.Aldred.casual@theGuardian.com. 16th over: England 43-1 (Denly 14, Bairstow 8) Bowling change, as Joseph replaces Gabriel. Denly manages to avoid repeating the first innings when he snicked the loosest of looseners through to the keeper, but is beaten by a lovely Joseph away-nipper before wearing a lifter on his hand. Still not easy out there. 15th over: England 43-1 (Denly 14, Bairstow 8) Bairstow jabs a pull off his thigh round the corner and sprints back for a second run, then after missing a cut he plays quite a careful pull from a stinking long-hop just in front of deep backward square, out to the boundary. Just as in the first knock, positivity from Bairstow here. 14th over: England 37-1 (Denly 14, Bairstow 2) Gabriel still steaming in, and he’s opting for a rib-tickling approach, pounding the middle of the track. One stays super low and Denly keeps it from hitting the stumps only with a thick inside edge, then he wafts at a rare full ball and misses with the drive. 13th over: England 37-1 (Denly 14, Bairstow 2) Hell’s teeth that was a dreadful shot by Burns. Bairstow is altogether more circumspect with the remaining five balls of the over, getting off the mark by flicking two into a vacant mid-wicket. Sheesh. Holder brings himself on and strikes first ball, but at the risk of being uncharitable it didn’t have much to do with him. Burns tries to cut a ball far, far too close to cut, and only succeeds in giving Campbell catching practice in the slips. 12th over: England 35-0 (Burns 16, Denly 14) Gabriel is giving off similar grumpy vibes to Anderson earlier. The nip has disappeared from his bowling and the two batsmen are finding it increasingly easy to play him. Just a single from the over. 11th over: England 34-0 (Burns 15, Denly 14) Denly clips pleasantly in front of mid-wicket, not quite timing it perfectly but he picks up another two runs, and as it turns out it was merely a precursor to an absolutely delicious cover drive that he very much did time perfectly, all the way to the cover fence. If you’re an England supporter who believes in fate-tempting look away now...but these two are looking more and more assured. 10th over: England 28-0 (Burns 15, Denly 8) Snorter from Gabriel who turns Burns right round, like a record baby, and he somehow avoids getting bat on the ball. Incidentally, Bairstow is padded up to come in first drop, despite keeping for four sessions. 9th over: England 28-0 (Burns 15, Denly 8) Burns jabs at one from Roach then looks behind him in panicked deja vu, the ball going extremely close to the stumps, much as it did in the first innings. But unlike that innings, it missed the wickets and he survives. 8th over: England 26-0 (Burns 14, Denly 7) Gabriel traps Denly and it looks very, very close: the bowler wants to review it but none of his teammates concur. Looked out at first glance, but Hawkeye confirms it was going a few inches over, so a good decision in the end. Denly looks uncomfortable in the extreme, but then Gabriel lets him off the hook with a wide long-hop that the Kent man cuts with gusto to the boundary. Then once more Denly gets away with one, cuffing an attempted pull straight up in the air, but it plops down just in front of a theoretical square leg. 7th over: England 21-0 (Burns 14, Denly 2) Burns looking a bit more positive: he whips a couple down to fine leg, plays a confident drive straight at extra-cover then times the knickers off a leg-stump half-volley, which fine leg fails to stop. There was a missed cut in there too, but the intent is there. 6th over: England 14-0 (Burns 8, Denly 1) Denly looks a tad skittish, all tip-toes and jerky bat movements. He pulls at one from Gabriel that keeps a little lower than expected and he misses in ugly fashion, but then he connects with one, sends a top edge high, high, high in the air towards fine leg where Brathwaite runs in....and DROPS! Those steeplers are always tricky but he made a complete nonsense of the attempt, misjudging things badly and not getting there quite in time. Gabriel screams then stares at the fielder for a long, long time. Gulp. Meanwhile: mercy, mercy me... 5th over: England 13-0 (Burns 8, Denly 0) Burns plays with soft hands, opening the face very slightly and guiding a thick outside edge down to third man for England’s first boundary off the bat. Roach comes back with the jaffa’s jaffa from the last ball of the over, which misses the edge but does square Burns up rather. The players are back out for the afternoon. You wonder how long West Indies will be able to keep up their barrage of that brief spell before lunch. If they can, this will be a super-spicy session for England. They’re playing highlights of Lara’s 375 in Antigua on Sky. Here’s a piece about that magnificent thing by Vic Marks, who watched from the press box that day. Pretty decent morning for England, really: the lead was only extended by 34 runs, and they’ve reached the break with all their wickets intact. A low bar, perhaps, but that’s frankly where England have set it on this tour so far. 4th over: England 9-0 (Burns 4, Denly 0) Burns takes a Trottian length of time to mark out his guard, just making sure this is the last over before lunch. He plays out the over well, not offering the bat unless he absolutely has to, flapping a single to fine leg and it is indeed the interval. A potentially grim little spell nicely dealt with by the openers. 3rd over: England 8-0 (Burns 3, Denly 0) Roach bowls with a hefty grunt, but Burns deals with him pretty well, nicely flicking a single down to fine leg. Denly shovels one to short-leg which Hetmyer drops, but that was all thigh pad. They go up for an ear-splitting lbw appeal but the angle from which Roach is bowling (wide) that looked like it was heading comfortably down leg. Shrewd call not to review it. 2nd over: England 7-0 (Burns 2, Denly 0) Here’s beefcake Shannon Gabriel to open from the other end, and sends a brutal bouncer towards Burns’s throat which he fends off as best he can, the ball flying to where leg gully would have been. Batting on this track against this pace looks...not fun. Meanwhile, the Antipodean mind games continue, with Justin Rigden: “Please remind Brian Withington that our bragging rights disappeared with that little scrap of sandpaper last year. I told you England would be batting in half an hour. If they survive until the last session today, it’s game on.” 1st over: England 6-0 (Burns 1, Denly 0) Quite a start from Roach - an absolutely colossal leg side wide gives a scrambling Dowrich no chance at all, and it flies away for five wides. Then the snortiest of snorter bouncers is aimed at Burns’s nose: a brilliant delivery, jagging in as well as being at that lethal length and pace, very well played by Burns who got out of the way, pronto. Burns tucks the first run off the bat just wide of mid-on. They’re out for England’s second innings. How will this water biscuit England top order cope with Roach, Gabriel et al? Great effort by Bravo, though. He reached 50 off 215 balls and in 338 minutes, which makes it the slowest ever half-century by a West Indian and the third slowest in all Test matches. Proper cricket, or something. Tough one for England, then. The bad news is this pitch is becoming more treacherous than the pit of Sarlaac, but the good news is West Indies have shown it’s possible to score some runs if you’re sensible about it. After Bravo brings up his half-century with a single, two balls of the over to go they for some reason take another single after a thump down to long-on by Gabriel. Bravo comes down the pitch to try working another to keep the strike, but just runs past it and Bairstow completes the formalities. 130th over: West Indies 304-9 (Bravo 49, Gabriel 0) Gabriel loses track of what I think was a shorter slower ball, but is again pretty staunchly in behind the rest of Stokes’s over. “Please advise Justin Ridgen (over 124),” advises Brian Withington, “that we are on to his canny reverse moxing of this match and the forthcoming Ashes series. Stick to the archetypal Antipodean bragging and sledging whilst leaving us Poms to the gentle deprecatory pursuit of downplaying our teams’ chances on all sporting fronts.” 129th over: West Indies 304-9 (Bravo 49, Gabriel 0) Bit of spin, as Mo Mo Mo Ali replaces Anderson. “Let’s not eff about Mo,” yells a voice from somewhere, I think the crowd rather than the field, but one would think the players will concur. Bravo turns down a single after carving one to the cover sweeper, which is a bit surprising, but then takes a step or two down and smokes a bullet straight six that barely got 10ft above the ground. However he can’t get the single from the final ball which means Stokes, in theory, has an over at Gabriel. 128th over: West Indies 298-9 (Bravo 43, Gabriel 0) England put three slips, a short leg and a leg gully in for Gabriel, but the big man gets in behind the rest of the over from Stokes pretty solidly, ducking under a couple of the shorter balls. Wicket maiden from Stokes though. Ben Stokes is on, and strikes with his very first ball, as Joseph fends one to Rory Burns, who takes a good low catch at third slip. That’s what you call instant impact. 127th over: West Indies 298-8 (Bravo 43, Joseph 7) Joseph takes a rapid single just past point, but speeds in and makes his ground, but the throw misses anyway. Meanwhile here’s a story from Ali Martin about the Hundred, which is going well. 126th over: West Indies 296-8 (Bravo 42, Joseph 6) Joseph fends at a couple of balls from Broad that leap up, inspiring the installation of a short leg. Joseph gets in solidly behind a few, before another pops up but too far ahead of Jennings to be dangerous. Digging in, with Darren Bravo: 125th over: West Indies 296-8 (Bravo 42, Joseph 6) Sheesh what a shot from Joseph: a ball of reasonably full length is thwacked high over Anderson head and it bounces through for a boundary. Bravo then plays a couple of shots that look a bit pointless and wafty, missing both, but then again he’s facing Jimmy Anderson on a minefield of a pitch, so... They’re having a drink. West Indies lead by 104 which, after the first hour, is a result for both teams: them because, well, they lead by 104, but England because they’ve broadly kept the scoring down. 124th over: West Indies 291-8 (Bravo 42, Joseph 1) Joseph plays a nice flick off his pads for a single. The optimistic Justin Rigden from earlier is back on - or, perhaps given his provenance, the pessimistic Justin Rigden. “I am an Australian and did watch England in the 1990s, with a great deal of satisfaction! This is a much better England team than that. They’ll be batting within half an hour - providing the top end are patient, they should make a game of it. They’ll beat Australia this year too.” 123rd over: West Indies 289-8 (Bravo 41, Joseph 0) Applause from all round the stadium as Alzarri Joseph makes his way out to the middle. He leaves one that misses off stump by...not a lot, and then takes one on his pads that England sort of appeal for, but their heart didn’t sound in it. Really, really good catch by Stokes: not a spectacular one really, because he didn’t have to move his feet and just threw his hands up high directly above his head, but a flashed edge from Roach was going at quite a pace. England chipping away now: Anderson and Broad have bowled rather well. 122nd over: West Indies 289-7 (Bravo 41, Roach 6) Bravo wears a nasty lifter from Broad on his bottom hand, and that looked like it bloody hurt. Glove off, hand gets a good shake, then next ball from almost the same length keeps very low and Bravo does brilliantly to jab his bat down in time. Then Broad bowls a couple of what look a lot like cutters, the first beats a defensive push and the next goes wide of a rare expansive shot from Bravo. The Windies have the last laugh (from that over) with a couple of singles. Meanwhile, this is flamboyantly niche... ...and while I’m not trying to explain the joke, any excuse to listen to one of the great songs. 121st over: West Indies 287-7 (Bravo 40, Roach 5) Roach jabs at one outside off and a very thick edge zoots wide of the diving Burns at fourth slip, earning himself (?) a boundary. 120th over: West Indies 282-7 (Bravo 39, Roach 1) You have to admire Kemar Roach’s moxy: he swings absolutely everything at a ball vaguely on a length, misses it by a foot and earns a quizzical look from Broad. 119th over: West Indies 282-7 (Bravo 39, Roach 1) Actually I did Anderson a disservice there: there was plenty of bounce, enough in fact to take Holder’s glove, rather than the bat. Anderson beats Bravo with a couple of absolutely snorting away swingers and, despite his continued grumpiness, looks in a pretty good groove. “Every time I see England selector Ed Smith in the crowd,” offers Don Wilson, “I’ve been trying to think who he reminds me of. Today I’ve got it, anyone remember 1980’s early CGi Max Headroom?” Judge for yourself... ...although I’ve always had him more as ‘Young Mick McCarthy if he went to Cambridge.’ Simple stuff. Anderson bowls one just the right width outside off stump, it lifts up just enough and flicks off Holders’s willow through to Bairstow. 118th over: West Indies 281-6 (Bravo 39, Holder 22) There’s a significant change in the field, as Root and Broad bring in a short leg and a sort of leg gully/wide leg slip, with one conventional slip and a gully. Not going to be much full stuff, you’d wager. Incidentally, should probably have mentioned earlier: that short-leg is Keaton Jennings, on the field again for Ben Foakes, so Jonny Bairstow is keeping. Jennings takes a sharp one-handed catch, but off Bravo’s thigh pad. Kandukuru Nagarjun writes: “Alzarri Joseph’s tragedy reminds me of another tragedy involving a Windies player that happened around an Antigua Test. In 1983 against India, the great Gordon Greenidge scored a century, his first for six years. And then flew back home to Barbados to be with his infant daughter battling a kidney infection. Sadly, she succumbed to it two days later.” 117th over: West Indies 281-6 (Bravo 39, Holder 22) Anderson lets out a gutteral scream of irritation as Holder edges between second and third slip, but it dropped about a foot short and in the end Stokes does brilliantly to stop the thing from scooting boundary-wards. Anderson beats the edge two more times, and turns on his heels with what can only be described as a dejected vibe. 116th over: West Indies 280-6 (Bravo 38, Holder 22) Broad hits Bravo above the knee roll and goes up for an appeal that could go in the dictionary as the definition of optimism. That’s what happens when desperation starts to creep in. One single from the over, nudged by Bravo. 115th over: West Indies 279-6 (Bravo 37, Holder 22) Holder leaves one on length, which is about as remarkable an act of faith as you can imagine in cricket. He was right though: just, the ball going about three or four inches over the bails. 114th over: West Indies 278-6 (Bravo 36, Holder 22) Broad gives Bravo a terrific lifter which the batsman does well to keep down but then, in a minor version of the stunt he pulled yesterday, the bowler pointlessly flicks the ball at the stumps, off which it rebounds, and the alert Windies pair skip through for a single. Then a sign of just how much this pitch is falling apart as one on a length leaps up so much that it loops through to the keeper - it was as if the ball had hit a pebble in the middle of the pitch. 113th over: West Indies 277-6 (Bravo 35, Holder 22) Absolute woofer of an in-ducker from Anderson to start, cutting Holder in half and from the sound of things it clipped his box. Then one holds its line and beats the outside edge, and the final ball of the over is the sort of sensational ball that even the best batsmen just has to close his eyes and hope misses the bat, pitching on middle-off and jagging away unplayably. Justin Rigden potentially didn’t grow up watching England in the 1990s, so thus sounds quite chipper. “Of course England will be batting today, the Windies tail is quite fragile. This pitch will be horrendous to bat on last. If England can get a lead of 100 they’re in with a good chance of victory.” 112th over: West Indies 277-6 (Bravo 35, Holder 22) Broad starts largely on the mark, but Holder gets some squirted runs, two down to third man and another one off a thick inside-edge to mid-wicket. Bravo tucks a couple of his own down to fine leg. And we’re away. The Barmy Army, as usual give themselves a hearty round of applause after the semi-tuneless version of Jerusalem. More sad news, from Antigua... As far as I know Joseph - just 22 - will still play, which always I find absolutely extraordinary. The mental fortitude that must take is remarkable. This has nothing to do with sport, never mind cricket, but before play starts read these tributes to Jeremy Hardy, who died this week. “Of course England will be batting at some point today,” says Nick Knight. Don’t be quite so sure about that, Nicholas. What’s the pitch going to be like today? Well, it looks like an eroding cliff, all jagged edges and unexpected crevices. I wouldn’t fancy batting on it, but then again I’m not even a village standard batsman. Batting last on this is going to be spicy, but batting second and third doesn’t look like a picnic either. And here’s Stuart Broad sounding either despondent or rather bullish, depending on how you view things. A quick catch-up from yesterday? Allow Victor Marks to take you through it. Do you think there’s a more frustrated set of sportspeople in the world right now than the England bowling attack? 276/6 isn’t a horrendous score to have conceded in isolation, even without the dropped catches. But of course there are the dropped catches, plus the house of cards collapse of the top order, which has meant that not horrendous score equates to what will soon be a first innings lead of 100, then 150 and most likely 200 plus after that. Naturally England didn’t bowl perfectly, and we’ll get to the West Indies batting prowess in a bit, but if the tourists’ current predicament is anyone specific’s fault, it ain’t the bowlers’. Naturally, the Guardian reserves the right to withdraw this commentary should we get another wicketless day with a whole load of pies sent down. Let’s see.

webTitle: West Indies thrash hapless England by 10 wickets to seal series victory

fields.headline: West Indies thrash hapless England by 10 wickets to seal series victory
fields.standfirst:
• Second Test day 3: England 187 & 132; West Indies 306 & 17-0
• West Indies win by 10 wickets to take 2-0 series lead
fields.trailText: England fell to a crushing 10-wicket defeat in Antigua after another miserable batting display in the second Test
fields.byline: Vic Marks at the Sir Vivian Richards Stadium
fields.body:
England have never won a Test in Antigua and their 10th attempt to do so ended rapidly and ignominiously. They were defeated inside three days by 10 wickets. Once again Joe Root’s tourists have been thoroughly outplayed from start to finish. Here was a pale imitation of the 80s and 90s except for the fact that the accepted wisdom before the series was that England were the favourites to win it. Now, with a match to go, Jason Holder’s side are already in proud possession of the Wisden Trophy and how they deserve it.

West Indies’ first-innings lead of 119 was more than enough to stay in charge of the game. Where the West Indian batsmen gritted their teeth and grafted, the English ones, disconcerted by a spicy pitch and a disciplined attack, found a variety of ways to be dismissed. Most of the home batsmen had to be bowled out, most of the visitors surrendered to blameless deliveries. Half-volleys were missed, straight balls shunned and of the batsmen only Joe Root was the recipient of a devilish delivery upon dismissal.

Related: Joe Root: ‘We came here to win but we have been outplayed, outperformed’

Not that the pitch was sleeping. There was still movement for the pacemen on a surface that reflected West Indies’ ambition in this series. There have been some torpid tracks in the recent past here but not on this tour. West Indies were prepared to take on England on lively pitches, confident that their batsmen and bowlers could match the tourists at their own game. And so they have, no matter that England’s opening bowlers share 1,008 wickets between them or that their batsmen are supposed to be accustomed to the moving ball.

Once again those batsmen were swept away after England had dispatched the last four West Indies players for 34 runs in the morning. The last man out was Darren Bravo, the solitary West Indian to reach 50 in an innings that exemplified a determination to grind out precious, ugly runs in a manner that was beyond this England lineup.

When stumped off Moeen Ali, Bravo had been at the crease for 331 minutes and had recorded the slowest ever half-century by a West Indian and the slowest by any Test cricketer since Mahela Jayawardene against New Zealand in 1998. Here was an example of how an innings of purposeful defence could have a major influence on the outcome of a Test match.

Related: Alzarri Joseph stands tall for West Indies despite death of his mother

England’s response was typically harum-scarum. Joe Denly thought his innings was all over before he had scored. And so did everyone else. He tried to pull a short delivery from Shannon Gabriel but he was never in control of the shot. The mis-hit sent the ball slowly in the direction of Kraigg Brathwaite at long leg, the most reliable batsman in the West Indian team, but maybe not the most reliable fielder.

Denly was aghast and stopped in the middle of the pitch, preparing for his doleful return to the pavilion. But the wind has been swirling all game; Brathwaite now found himself in a poor position; suddenly he had to dive and the ball escaped his grasp. Denly had been watching and before scurrying down the pitch to register his first run he collided with the bowler, who was now the man aghast.

The supreme English optimist might have been tempted to see this aberration as the trigger for a long-awaited turning of the tide. But that would have been wishful thinking. The wickets soon tumbled anyway.

After his reprieve Denly delivered a princely square cut and cover drive but it was not long before he watched three batsmen head off disconsolately towards the pavilion.

Both Rory Burns and Jonny Bairstow fell to Jason Holder, the slowest of the West Indian quartet but the canniest. Burns had been busy, clipping the ball off his legs adeptly but he offered insufficient respect to Holder’s first delivery. It possessed no demons but it was too close to the body for the cut shot. So he ended up guiding the ball, rather like Trevor Bayliss does in those early morning catching routines, straight into the hands of John Campbell at third slip. It was another cheap dismissal, which had not been a characteristic of the West Indies innings.

Out came Bairstow, bristling. He struck two boundaries but there was no air of permanence. His dismissal mirrored that of his first innings. A full-length delivery invited the drive, but aiming to the leg side Bairstow played around the ball and the stumps were disturbed.

Now England were 49 for two and the climb back into the game was ever steeper. Root’s first scoring shot, a leg-glance, just eluded the gloves of Shane Dowrich before speeding to the boundary. Then came another masterstroke from Holder in the form of a review. He spotted an inside edge on to the thigh better than the umpire Christopher Gaffaney and the England captain was gone, caught by the keeper, off Alzarri Joseph. The bowler had not bothered to appeal, which was hardly surprising since he was still reeling from the death of his mother, Sharon, overnight. Yet he had chosen to seek solace in the warmth of the West Indies’ dressing room.

Then Denly’s second Test innings adventure was over. Once again Joseph was the bowler but the batsman was the culprit. Denly shouldered arms and the ball clattered into his off-stump – 59 for four and the ship was sinking.

Ben Stokes and Moeen Ali were bowled driving at Kemar Roach without due care and attention and the tail could not wag. Jos Buttler’s 24 was the highest score, which was more than Keaton Jennings’ 17 in the first innings in Barbados. However, no other improvements have been discernible here in Antigua.

Joe Denly thought his innings was all over before he had scored. And so did everyone else. He tried to pull a short delivery from Shannon Gabriel but he was never in control of the shot. The mis-hit sent the ball slowly in the direction of Kraigg Brathwaite at long leg, the most reliable batsman in the West Indian team, but maybe not the most reliable fielder. Denly was aghast and stopped in the middle of the pitch, preparing for his doleful return to the pavilion. But the wind has been swirling all game; Brathwaite now found himself in a poor position; suddenly he had to dive and the ball escaped his grasp. Denly had been watching and before scurrying down the pitch to register his first run he collided with the bowler, who was now the man aghast. The supreme English optimist might have been tempted to see this aberration as the trigger for a long-awaited turning of the tide. But that would have been wishful thinking. The wickets soon tumbled anyway. After his reprieve Denly delivered a princely square cut and cover drive but it was not long before he watched three batsmen head off disconsolately towards the pavilion. Both Rory Burns and Jonny Bairstow fell to Jason Holder, the slowest of the West Indian quartet but the canniest. Burns had been busy, clipping the ball off his legs adeptly but he offered insufficient respect to Holder’s first delivery. It possessed no demons but it was too close to the body for the cut shot. So he ended up guiding the ball, rather like Trevor Bayliss does in those early morning catching routines, straight into the hands of John Campbell at third slip. It was another cheap dismissal, which had not been a characteristic of the West Indies innings. Out came Bairstow, bristling. He struck two boundaries but there was no air of permanence. His dismissal mirrored that of his first innings. A full-length delivery invited the drive, but aiming to the leg side Bairstow played around the ball and the stumps were disturbed. Now England were 49 for two and the climb back into the game was ever steeper. Root’s first scoring shot, a leg-glance, just eluded the gloves of Shane Dowrich before speeding to the boundary. Then came another masterstroke from Holder in the form of a review. He spotted an inside edge on to the thigh better than the umpire Christopher Gaffaney and the England captain was gone, caught by the keeper, off Alzarri Joseph. The bowler had not bothered to appeal, which was hardly surprising since he was still reeling from the death of his mother, Sharon, overnight. Yet he had chosen to seek solace in the warmth of the West Indies’ dressing room. Then Denly’s second Test innings adventure was over. Once again Joseph was the bowler but the batsman was the culprit. Denly shouldered arms and the ball clattered into his off-stump – 59 for four and the ship was sinking. Ben Stokes and Moeen Ali were bowled driving at Kemar Roach without due care and attention and the tail could not wag. Jos Buttler’s 24 was the highest score, which was more than Keaton Jennings’ 17 in the first innings in Barbados. However, no other improvements have been discernible here in Antigua.
